course.subject: FINA
course.name: Financial Management
course.description: For SB&M students only. This course provides an introduction to corporate finance. Topics include time value of money, bond and stock valuation, capital budgeting, risk and return concepts and cost of capital.
course.prerequisites: ACCT 2010 AND (CIVL 2160 OR IEDA 2510 (prior to 2018-19) OR IEDA 2540 OR ISOM 2500 OR LIFS 3150 OR MATH 2411)

reviews.author: kronigiri
reviews.title: Only reg Peter Mackay if you have the sauce
reviews.comment_content:
Course content is well-designed. First half is about basic Fina concepts like time value of money, present & future values, normal firm cash flows, and calculation of perpetuity, annuity, and bond values. It is easy to fall behind a little but the content is actually not that hard (most of the calculation questions can be solved by applying the formulas)

Calculations are more difficult in the first half than the later half imo, but there are more formulas to remember after midterm. Topics include mainly equity and project valuation, capital budgeting, and costs of capital.

2 lessons each week but only need to go to one, the first lesson each week is replaced by an online video lecture.

For Peter Mackay, MT was conducted online on Canvas, with 2/3 conceptual MC questions and the remaining calculation short questions. Due to the instructor's absurd laziness, FT is face-to-face 40 MC questions, also 2/3 conceptual and 1/3 calculations. MT was open-book and Final allows a 2-sided A4 cheatsheet.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Fucking hideous, for 2 main reasons.

Course content is fine as aforementioned, according to the textbook (same publisher as ACCT 2010, with a lot of practice exercises and quizzes which is useful af) You can self-study the textbook smoothly. However, Peter tends to deviate from the textbook and teaches as he likes, while not giving a fuck about supplementary materials. So there is no way to practice or study those extra stuff on your own. I self-study the entire textbook and is completely lost doing Peter's quizzes.

Also, this bloke is the laziest ass I have ever seen. He claims the  Canvas quiz questions are from a large question base, yet I see the same questions 6 times, in iPRS, then in the weekly quiz, then in mock MT, MT, mock Final, and final. How the fuck can I differentiate myself from the other students if all we have to do to score high is to memorise the answers. Even his Zoom lecture videos are pre-recorded and used across the 4 lecture classes he teaches. This guy even suggested to conduct the final in the Sports Hall via bloody Canvas, so he doesn't have to mark the papers. At last he still doesnt have to mark the papers because even the calculation questions are MCs. Fuck this guy.

However, if you already have most of the questions and the sources, you can just memorise most of the questions and you will be very happy to find them again in the papers.
reviews.comment_grading:
12% weekly canvas quiz of 5 questions (best 10 out of 13)
16% 4 homework assignments (10 questions, 2 attempts)
4% iPRS every class (top 10 iPRSs)
28% Midterm
40% Cumulative Final

Because most questions are like neighbours you see everyday and therefore nearly half the class are familiar with them, the average is quite high.

If you want to half-ass this course then Peter is the instructor for you. But if you want to score high for major selection then this bloke is the worst prof you can ever choose.

So angry after the final so I wrote this review before my grades are out. Will update my grade later.
reviews.comment_workload: Very heavy workload if you want to fully understand all the topics. I spent 80% of my semester's study time only on this course.

reviews.author: 清水灣Q王
reviews.title: Useful course and very competitive
reviews.comment_content:
The original plan:
Chapter 1: Corporate Finance and the Financial Manager (exclude 1.2)
Chapter 3: Time Value of Money: An Introduction
Chapter 4: Time Value of Money: Valuing Cash Flow Streams
Chapter 5: Interest Rates (exclude 5.3)
Chapter 8: Investment Decision Rules (exclude Modified IRR in 8.3, and 8.6)
Chapter 2: Introduction to Financial Statement Analysis (exclude 2.5-2.7)
Midterm exam (Chapters  1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8)
Chapter 9: Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting (exclude 9.5, 9.6, and MACRS)
Chapter 6: Bonds
Chapter 7: Stock Valuation;
Chapter 10: Stock Valuation: A Second Look (exclude 10.4 and 10.5)
Chapter 11: Risk and Return in Capital Markets
Chapter 12: Systematic Risk and the Equity Risk Premium
Chapter 13: Cost of Capital
Final Exam (Chapters 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13)

However, due to the time limit, chapters 10 and 13 were not covered which is honestly a shame as those are interesting topics as well.
I would say these chapters provide a solid foundation for business students who aim to major in FINA or QFIN or take any further FINA courses in general. This course also gives a good indicator to whether you are interested in majoring in FINA related majors or not-if you hate this course then maybe seek other majors of your interest.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Pi is a nice professor. She always attempted to interact in class and make friends with us, some of us even troll along in the chatbox and she went along with it. In class, she always tried her hardest to explain the concepts in finance by drawing diagrams and visualization. However, as this semester is online, it is quite often that she encounters technical problems, like problems with IPRS and breakout rooms, which kind of worsen our learning experience. All in all, I would say that she is decent at teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
A. Class participation 10%
Class participation is divided into two parts. One part is the IPRS question (by attendance), and another part is the breakout room exercise (1 PDF submission per group within 30 minutes after the lecture ends). I should get almost full marks in this.
B. 11 MFL homework assignments (best 10)--> [best 8 of 9] 16%
Due to syllabus cutting, it changed to the best 8 of 9 assignments. I got full marks in 7 of them, remaining two are 94% and 86% respectively. Be sure to double-check before checking answers as those counts towards your grade.
C. Online Quizzes (2) 4%
The first online quiz is super difficult and the mean is around 4/8, I got 5/8.
The second online quiz is much easier and many got full or near full marks, I got 6/6.
D. Midterm Exam 30%
The midterm exam is quite difficult and the mean is around 68/92 (8 marks are for bonus), I got near full marks for this.
E. Final Exam (non-cumulative) 40%
The final exam is easier. Although there are no mean or other statistical figures, I guess the mean will be in the mid-70s. I got 80 something for the final, probably because of some careless mistakes.

I got A finally and I don't know what to say about the grading, it could be tough or lenient depending on your point of view. Personally I am satisfied with my grade, but for other classmates, some worked their ass off throughout the semester but got B and B- finally, so it may be unfair to some. However, one thing that I could say is that this course is super competitive, and don't expect to get into the A-range paying subpar efforts.
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say the workload really depends on your ambition.
Some people who are ambitious (A-range hunter) would spend hours on practising the question banks on Pearson MyFinanceLab before quizzes and exams, while others would not be as diligent.
In terms of the course requirement, there is basically an online homework every week and it takes around half an hour to finish (9 in total this semester). So most workload lies in self-studying for the quizzes and midterms, constant effort should be made to achieve high.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Really bad. I have never seen a professor like this.
He has nearly no lecture notes or slides. He just writes down somethings on a piece of paper, and then keeps talking on it. He will have nearly 2-3 pieces of paper, and finishes his lecture on that day.
He always shares international business news to us and let us watch those videos in the lecture. But we don't know what is the importance of watching those videos and what is the relationship between those videos and our course.
He sometimes cancels his lessons due to his meetings overseas or personal reasons, and he will have makeup lessons on Saturday or upload videos on Canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Marks came out very quickly as there are only MC questions.
Mean is terribly high even quizzes and exams are difficult.
- Class Participation: 5%
- MyFinance Lab: 15%
- Homework: 15%
- Midterm: 25%
- Final: 40%

For class participation, it will be done through iPRS. However, you must attend your own section in order to get class participation mark. Even you attend another lecture section and finish the iPRS, it will not be counted.

Grade distribution is not specified. But if you do all MFL and attend section properly, 20% of marks will be guaranteed.

-
Update
-
Very good grade!!!!! Out of my surprise!!!!
Never got above mean or even a pass except MFL quizzes and attendance mark.
All homework failed & midterm below 1.5 s.d, & final below 0.5 s.d. => B-
reviews.comment_workload:
Very heavy workload.
There are 13 weeks in one semester, and there are 10 MFL quiz, 1midterm and 1 final exam.
-
For MFL quiz,
step 1) Do all practice questions
step 2) Go to the Quiz Me part to do the quiz on this chapter
step 3) Get 80% correct in Quiz Me and get 1 Mastery Point
step 4) Finish all Quiz Me to get 5 MP
step 5) Work on the quiz (you will have 2 chances)
If you cannot get 80% correct in the Quiz Me, go and work from the first step.
-
For the homework, it will be done on Canvas. Most of the questions are MC, some are fill in the blanks. Problems are really long and hard, it takes a long time to read the questions and understand what it means. You will have 3hours to finish 10 questions.
-
If you do not aim at learning but just for good grade, goyal is suitable for you :)

reviews.author: A_A
reviews.title: Not too bad
reviews.comment_content: Throughout the course, you will learn some very basic knowledge about finance, for instance, how to calculate PV and CAPM. You will also some corporate finance theory, for instance WACC and M&M theory. I guess the course materials were easy and basic in a nutshell.
reviews.comment_teaching: I guess his notes is clear. But I felt a little bit difficult to adapt into his approach of teaching. He counted participation mark as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
There were 2 midterm exams and 1 final exam. Since the exams were quite easy, the mean and median were quite high. The calculation usually was easy and straight forward. So the key to tackle with the exam was to be extremely careful.

For your reference, I got an A at the end with the following marks:
Midterm 1: 93.75/100
Midterm 2: 95.34/100
Final exam: 95.45/100

Some peers of mine got a slight higher/lower score than mine resulted in an A+/B+.
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload was mild. You only needed to deal with the online assignments and few exams. Since the exam and assignment questions were easy, it usually won't spend you too much time on them.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy. You have MFL as an assignment almost every week (10 in total). You have only one attempt and can not make any mistakes in order to get the 10%. 9 best MFL out of 10 will count towards 10%. Remember to use STUDY PLAN in MFL! Since I sometimes could not catch up in class, I usually spend extra time on the textbooks. The other workload mainly from reading the textbook and doing practice questions. It helps a lot since class exercise is not enough. If you take her course, expect to do more self-revision.
Attendance is not required. But there is Ureply like IPRS so you may need your friend to send you the class code. She randomly does the Ureply so I think it's better to attend class.

He literally taught nothing, filled the whole lecture with useless iprs, boring jokes and his sleepy accent.

reviews.author: Gerry
reviews.comment_content:
Very basic introduction to finance concepts
1. Financial Statement Analysis
2.Fundamentals of Valuation
3.Valuation of Bonds
4.Valuation of Stocks
5.Net Present Value Rule and Creation of Value
6.Project Evaluation
7.Cost of Equity, Cost of Debt and Cost of Capital

The content itself is basic and not difficult to grasp with effort and time, and if you don't have a professor that confuses you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor knows the stuff he needs to teach, but doesn't seem to have any idea of how to deliver it to students who have little to no background in finance.

At the beginning of the semester, he seemed to have very grave misconceptions of the foundation knowledge that the students had. He gave questions that a lot of us did not understand, much less how to break down. Even with explanations, we were too lost due to knowledge gap. It took a good 3-4 weeks before he turned it down a notch and kind of realized how basic the course was needed to be.

Only made powerpoints for add-drop period, and maybe 1 or 2 additional lectures. The rest of the lectures were essentially spent on mostly off he top of his head questions, and working on them on blank sheets of paper, as well as Yahoo Finance. These papers would then be uploaded and titled "lecture notes". Really not that useful if you don't understand the concepts themselves.

Even at the end, I don't think he actually realized how much we didn't know, nor how little he learnt from his teaching. He could be a little condescending at times, particularly after taking iPRS and seeing the majority of the class got the wrong answer despite it being "straight-forward".

Cannot comment on tutorials, was never able to attend due to schedule overlap.

I learnt more from My Finance Lab and taking notes from the textbook than I ever did in the lectures. If you have this professor, know that the lectures will most likely not be useful. Sleep through it, until iPRS, then self-study.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendend nearly all lectures for iPRS, and completed MFL fully.

1 HW above mean, 2 HW below mean.

Midterm 0.5 SD above mean

Final 1 SD below mean

Surprisingly B-. No idea how that happened but I am forever thankful.
reviews.comment_workload:
Terrible workload, but due to the bad lectures, I probably would have failed this course without it.

Finance easily took up at least 8 hours of my time per week. 3 hours of lectures, average 3-4 hours on MFL, 2-3 hrs/HW, on top of additional self study and note taking. For something so basic, it should definitely not have taken this much time to learn. If anything, the lectures confused me rather than taught. Can't blame the professor wholly, I also found it difficult to focus at 9AM, but the professor is a large factor.

There is a study plan in the FINA2303 required course website 'myFinance lab'. It has all the exercise of each chapter, with steps and answers included. Go through the questions before exams and understand the logic behind each question. Very useful and effective method to score high marks in exam. E.    Final Exam (non-cumulative) 40%

Both my midterm and final are below 1sd, so I get a C.  The mean is around 65-70% for both midterm and final.
reviews.comment_workload:
You will have 10 MFL homework (revision for each chapter), 2 quizes,1 mid term, and 1 final.

Not very heavy workload, there will be 10 questions for each homework and you can copy it from study plan, so it's quite easy to finish and get full mark.
The quizes only contains 2% but it helps you to do revision for mid term and final.

reviews.author: wyluk
reviews.title: A manageable introductory course
reviews.comment_content:
• Time Value of Money
• Interest rate
• Investment decision rules
• Measuring cash flow
• Capital Budgeting
• Bond valuation
• Stock valuation
• Risk and return in capital markets
• Systematic risk and equity risk premium
• Cost of capital
As this is an introductory course, the content is rather easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is average, she is willing to answer students' questions but sometimes unclear. I usually cannot catch up during class, so I have to spend for at least 2 hours after each class to review. Her pace in class was quite fast and you have to pay extra attention in order to follow her teaching. The TA Katy was not helpful in answering questions, and she took a long time to release the grades.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good.
MFL hw: 95% on average
Quiz 1: 85.71/100 (mean: 5x)
Quiz 2: 100/100 (mean:62.2%)
Midterm: 96.7/100 (mean:69.95%)
Final: 84.85/100 (I forgot the mean... it should be around 7x%)
A+
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite heavy. About one MFL hw per week (there are a total of 10 hw). There are two quizzes, one MT and one final. You should expect to spend at least 5-6 hours per week in revision (in addition to the lesson time).

reviews.author: samuelllr
reviews.comment_content: This course includes many fundamental finance concepts and its the major selection course of Finance major. So the competition is quite keen since many students want to get a good grade to choose Finance major. Fina 2303 provides an introduction to corporate finance. Topics include the time value of money, bond and stock valuation, capital budgeting, risk, and return concepts, and cost of capital. You are required to purchase the ebook published by Pearson. For face-to-face lectures, you may need to buy a finance calculator for your exam and exercise. However, for online lectures, you are free to use different software during the exam and exercise. You can use excel to do the calculations.
reviews.comment_teaching: The accent of the professor is strange but Ekkachai is a very funny and nice professor. He will open some news and share with us the latest financial events before every lesson. Apart from teaching the finance knowledge, Ekkachai also teaches us how to use excel to do the calculations.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is not good, In the midterm, my score was above the mean 1 standard deviation. For the quiz, my score was above the mean 0.8 standard deviations and slightly above the mean in the final. Full mark in assignments except missing one assignment. I got B at the end.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost no workload all you need to do is finish the online assignment every week which takes you less than 1 hour. This semester attendance is not compulsory. For revision, I suggest you to finish the supplementary exercises in the pearson website which is quite similar to the one in the exam.

reviews.author: jona_fhl
reviews.title: Good Professor, choose Ekkachai if you really want to learn Finance
reviews.comment_content:
Pretty basic introductory finance stuff. Mainly about the time value of money and introduction to valuation.

Detailed course syllabus is mentioned in other reviews so I won't attach it here.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ekkachai has a bit of accent, but it shouldn't be too hard for you to understand as long as you pay attention to his teaching. One thing I like about his teaching is that he always goes through Bloomberg news of the day with us before starting the class, which also makes him more 'interesting' than other ust professors.

In class he always makes sure he teaches everything that is in the syllabus, and he also uses other diagrams/excel to assist him in teaching instead of just showing us the powerpoint. The powerpoint slides are really useful, make sure you download all of them and go through all the sample questions on it.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair. For my term, there is one quiz, one mid term and one final, all of similar difficulty, didn't feel that final was more difficult than mid term.

Attendance doesn't count, but if you want to score high in exams, attend his lessons or at least go through the powerpoint slides.

Make sure you do practice questions on MyFinanceLab, they are really useful if you are uncertain about one or two topics.

Grading weighting:
Quiz 5%
MyFinanceLab Assignments 15%
Midterm 35%
Final 45%

Make sure you study for the midterm and final, as people tend to score high marks in them.
reviews.comment_workload:
The quiz, midterm and final will take up quite some time for studying, however, other than that, the workload is pretty low.

You will have to do online assignments on a platform called MyFinanceLab (whose server is always down during periods before exams). There are 11 assignments in total, but it will only count in the highest 10 you submit. You can try as many times as long as you score full marks, and there are tips to teach you how to get the answer whenever you submit a wrong answer.

reviews.author: ccp99
reviews.title: Super Nice Professor
reviews.comment_content: The content was useful since it included the fundamentals of all calculations in finance.
reviews.comment_teaching: Emilio was a nice professor. He tried his best to teach and made sure all of us understand. His midterm was easy but final was very hard. The TAs were nice too since they replied email quickly.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was lenient, I got 1.5sd above mean in midterm and 1sd above mean in final, all my marks in MFL were nearly full mark, my final grade was A.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was fair. MFL for every two chapters, 1 midterm and 1 final, 1 iprs for each lecture.

reviews.author: aloafofmeat
reviews.title: Swap Swap Swap
reviews.comment_content: It's hell if you don't like numbers, but it's compulsory so good luck lol
reviews.comment_teaching:
Maybe it's because she's teaching for the first year, but I don't think it's an excuse for being as bad as she is.

First off, she only reads off her slides, which often have typos and mistakes in numbers. You could be better off reading from the actual textbook, as she doesn't add a lot to the material anyways.

Her accent is hard to understand and her ability to explain concepts are weak. Almost all of my friends couldn't understand what she was referring to/what she wanted to explain.

A couple times I tried to her about some confusing concepts/questions, but she didn't answer me directly and I get a feeling she doesn't even know the answer to most of them. She often gets stumped by questions some students ask her in class as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Physical attendance is not required, but you can get participation marks by answering questions and getting cards. She never said how many you need to get to get full marks. Advice: sit in the front rows to increase chance of getting picked, and it doesn't matter what you answer/say/ask.

Sometimes she uses iLearn (kind of like iPRS) in class, but we never knew if it counted towards participation we just assumed so.

The curve isn't that harsh; if you have studied and know the concepts you will be at least mean (which says a lot about this course's difficulty for the majority of students)
reviews.comment_workload:
MyFinanceLab homework approximately once a week, it's a bit challenging but most of the questions are similar to the ones in slides, and you can practice the questions in the Study Guide so shouldn't be hard to get full marks, it just takes up a lot of time.

Midterm was ok, not easy but not very hard.
Final was very hard.

reviews.author: AL_
reviews.title: Super BAD GRADE
reviews.comment_content: As everyone mentioned, I think it is just the same for every year.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is quite funny. But his lesson is chur and a lot of iPRS, which is quite difficult.
reviews.comment_grading:
It depends on how you judge it. As everyone said, Ekkachai's class has a really high mean and the exam are quite hard. The highest mark of Multiple choices mid term is only 35/36. You need to work really hard to get a B range.
One of my friends get below 2 SD for both midterm and only do 6/8 of the assignment still get C- but not D. So the grading depends on your target I think.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite hard. The concepts is not simple and you need to do a lot of exercise. The assignments are annoying since you have 3 chances for calculation questions but only 1 chances for MC. You need to be well-prepared for the assignment in order to get nearly full mark.

reviews.author: Minal
reviews.title: Take it with this instructor if you are fine doing this course on your own!
reviews.comment_content:
The course material is quite interesting - you'll learn topics like WACC, CAPM etc
You'll be doing investment and financial policy (in a broader sense)
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof uploads voice-over-slides which you'll have to review before each class since each class will have an iprs based on the slides. In class, the prof goes over in-class activities only. All in all, you're mostly on your own in this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course is quite competitive.
mid-term 1:21/30
mid-term2:28/30
final: 41/45
overall: 91/100
grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: You'll have 2 mid-terms, 1 final, iprs sessions and homework problems to complete. It is quite manageable with a bit of effort.

He is so cute! He looked quite serious in the first few lessons perhaps this year is his 1st year in UST. Yet, he slowly showed us his lovely side to us. He would suddenly make some gags and jokes in class and you did not expect at all. And when people were late or early leave, he would say hi/bye/no! don't leave ok?

The bad thing is his powerpoint slides were so badly made. He almost made mistakes in all of the slides and he kept uploading the correct version after class so the notes would be quite messy, especially for those who hand-written notes. And sometimes we would not understand his work at all. We just sat there and opened our mouth as we really did not know what was happening.
reviews.comment_grading:

Another workload is the content itself. People who are weak at maths should put more effort into revising the content as many people will study hard to get a good grade in this course in order to enter FINA major.

Not yet known.

Ordered according to the teaching order
==============================================
Overall, most of the content of this course is based on what you've learned in ACCT 2010 such as financial statements and the others.

Overall difficulty: Intermediate  (I'd say it mostly depend on your understanding of some key concepts in ACCT 2010)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Ekkachai's teaching is overall good and detailed.
> Style: concrete and efficient, also easy to understand.
             He will provide enough examples for you to understand most kinds of situations, and will enlighten you when encountering some other new cases.

> Highlight: Market news update and analysis.
              Before the start of textbook content each class, prof will share some latest market news and his own thoughts with you. And, if you want to hear this, you need to come early.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 33/36
Final: haven't posted yet
Homework: 11/11 (100%)
Grade: A-

Since this course is the benchmark for application of FINA major, so it is relatively and reasonably more competitive.
Overall, I would say it is satisfactory.
reviews.comment_workload:
Overall: intermediate

Again, in my opinion, it mostly depends on your own understanding level of ACCT 2010. Admittedly, there are many new formulas and concepts. Many basic concepts still stand on the concepts in ACCT 2010. So if you are robust enough in ACCT 2010, chances are that you won't struggle and may feel just fine about this course.

In‐Class Activities (ICA) – 13 meetings (20 hrs)
Homework assignments – 4 homework assignments (20 hrs)
Self‐study and review (textbook readings and practice problems) (40 hrs)

The workload is not that heavy, but still, you have to catch up with the contents he taught every lecture in order to complete the quizzes every Sunday. Since this course is competitive (if you are aiming for a finance major), you have to work hard to understand everything.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Poor teaching, Do not understand a single thing he say.
Can only rely on his powerpoint.

Blended teaching mode, One physical lesson one video lesson.

This course is delivered in “blended-learning” mode. The formal lectures are replaced by Voiced-Over Slide (VOS)
stacks, which students should view ahead of the related In-Class Activity (ICA). This has several benefits: 1) Students
need only come to class once a week instead of twice. However, students must spend the time normally spent in
class for a traditional lecture to review the VOS in preparation for the ICA. There is no “free lunch”. 2) Our time
together in class (face-to-face or virtually) can be spent productively, covering applications of the material. 3) This
format allows students to better manage their time according to their own needs and preferred study style. The
VOS can be viewed at will and harder passages can be reviewed as needed, after or before reading the textbook.
Exams & quizzes will reflect a balance of textbook & VOS material, ICA sessions, and homework & practice problems.

reviews.author: TCT
reviews.comment_content:
Quite useful.

This course provides an introduction to corporate finance for students who have a basic background in accounting and business statistics. Topics include financial statement analysis, time value of money, bond and stock valuation, capital budgeting, risk and return concepts, and cost of capital.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Totally self-study

This course is delivered in “blended-learning” mode. The formal lectures are replaced by Voiced-Over Slide (VOS) stacks, which students should view ahead of the related In-Class Activity (ICA). This has several benefits: 1) Students need only come to class once a week instead of twice. However, students must spend the time normally spent in class for a traditional lecture to review the VOS in preparation for the ICA. There is no “free lunch”. 2) Our time together in class (face-to-face or virtually) can be spent productively, covering applications of the material. 3) This format allows students to better manage their time according to their own needs and preferred study style. The VOS can be viewed at will and harder passages can be reviewed as needed, after or before reading the textbook. Exams & quizzes will reflect a balance of textbook & VOS material, ICA sessions, and homework & practice problems.
reviews.comment_grading: Very competitive course, and the final exam is very similar (even same) with the weekly mini quiz
reviews.comment_workload: 1 hour video, 1chapter textbook, and 1 lesson (useless) each week

reviews.author: JT168
reviews.title: A complete guide for this course for non-excellent students
reviews.comment_content: The content is a basic introduction to finance, which is useful and practical. Many of the content is easy and straightforward. Only some parts in IRR, project cash flow analysis, and dividend discount model are difficult. But these concepts could still be cleared by reading the textbook many many times.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching of her class is fast (about 1 chapter per week). It could be a blessing or curse depending on your learning habit. If you would like to get a good grade, try to pre-study the textbook before class and study lesson materials after class. You would learn clearly and gain more understanding of the content than your classmates.

IPRS and Breakout room exercises would be done every lesson and participation would be counted in every class. Try to attend every lesson to get full marks in attendance.
reviews.comment_grading:
As many students would like to declare a finance major, the competition in this course is expected to be fierce.
However, I have to mention that the grading in this session is lenient. Let me repeat this important fact three times:
The grading in this course is lenient and good.
The grading in this course is lenient and good.
The grading in this course is lenient and good.
Despite I didn't get more than 90% overall, I still managed to get an A-.

Homework    15%
Participation   7%
Quiz               3%
Mid-term        35%
Exam             40%

For quizzes, be careful about the questions as they are tricky. Study hard too as it counts as 3% of the course grade.

The midterm is definitely difficult, despite I studied hard, the mean and sd are super high such that I cannot get above the mean for 0.5 sd. It is quite sad and disappointing. Be careful in your calculations to avoid careless mistakes.

Some other reviews mentioned that the final exam is difficult. However, I think that it is actually easier than the midterm with less complicated calculations. Just have more practice in my finance lab, then you would be fine. With hard work and clear concepts, I got well above mean a lot and got the second highest mark in the class.

If you want to get a good grade, try to understand every important concept in class as there are conceptual questions in assessments, and some questions might be slightly changed from the usual practices and rely on your real understanding of the formulas. These questions would be the ones that help your mark stands out under a high mean.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is acceptable with 1 assignment per work. Try to do the MFL study plan before doing your homework. The homework questions are mostly the same as the MFL study plan. Do multiple times study plans until you have got the right answer for each question. I got a full mark here.

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lynn Pi is a nice professor and always interact with us in class. Her teaching is also good and easy to follow. However, there are a lots of breakout room exercises (1-3 each class) and the submission would be counted towards participation as well as final grade. The grouping are random, if your groupmate doesn't work, you have to finish the tasks alone (some are easy some are challenging). This is the downside of this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment Methods:
A. Class participation - 7%
B. 11 MFL homework assignments (best 10) - 15%
C. Online Quiz 1 - 1%; Online Quiz 2 - 2%
D. Midterm Exam - 35%
E. Final Exam (non-cumulative) - 40%

Grades Statistics (Low,Mean,High):
A. Class participation - 7% (Out of 100: 14.4, 85.2, 100)
B. 11 MFL homework assignments (best 10) - 15% (Out of 100: 13.9, 93.5, 100)
C. Online Quiz 1 - 1% (Out of 100: 0, 54, 100)
    Online Quiz 2 - 2% (Out of 100: 0, 62.4, 100)
D. Midterm Exam - 35% (Out of 100: 0, 63.7, 96.4)
E. Final Exam (non-cumulative) - 40% (Out of 100: 21.3, 61.2, 89)

Overall, I scored 81% and the final grade is B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
SUPER HEAVY WORKLOAD.

There are My Finance Lab HW (11 in total). There are only 2 attempts for each question. If you want to score high in HW, you have to finish ALL of the practice questions provided. Hence, the workload is unbelievably huge. Although you can skip the exercise and work on the HW directly, it's not suggested since most people score 95%+ which is difficult to be achieved without practicing.

reviews.comment_teaching: Emo哥的讲课很有趣，他是一个很好的教授，你能感觉到亲切感。他喜欢鼓励同学开摄像头，这样他就能看到学生对于授课内容的反应。在课后他也会解答学生们提出的问题。助教Otto也是个nice person，他会认真解答你关于作业或者课堂内容的问题。
reviews.comment_grading:
Individual MFL Assignments (8) 30
Midterm 30%（满分100，平均71）
Final 40%（满分100 平均70）
MFL需要时刻记住ddl否则你会得到0分。期末考试是non-cumu,但是期中之前的内容会在之后的部分有所体现。教授会有复习题exercise，因此要好好做题复习。期末考试中有一些关于概念本质的题目是比较tricky的。我在期末考试发挥不佳，因此拿到a-，还是比较失望的。
总分90以上你可以拿到A range.因此你需要刻苦
reviews.comment_workload: 工作量不算大，相对于这样一门3分的课程来讲。当你真正理解了课堂的知识之后，就能轻易地做完My Finance Lab上的大部分题目。而且教授允许我们的错误在两次以内，在一遍错误的时候会有答案提示。所以MFL的作业对于我来说不算难事。但是作业的频率有时一周一次，因此你需要按着教授讲课的速度学完相应的知识才能做题，你不能到学期末一口气补完全部课应付考试。MFL有时系统不能进入，教授还会相应延长作业的ddl，因此是很人性化的了。

reviews.author: nononope
reviews.title: Great intro to Finance, and really all the skills you need to get jobs in Finance
reviews.comment_content:
covers all parts of finance imo, but again more on a surface level, as this is a kind of intermediate introductory course i would say. Great skills regardless of whichever industry you want to get in, and also great stuff for personal finance, really timeless concepts and principles covered in his class

Topics I liked - Stock Valuation, Bonds, Capital Budgeting, Risk & Return and Time Value of Money
reviews.comment_teaching:
Loved his teaching, really passionate and considerate about his course and students, TA was also very helpful, stayed up the night of final exam to answer students questions and sent a really nice email to cheer everyone up before the final to ease the tension, people had their cameras off and there was no participation required so he used to feel weird talking to black screens which is fair actually, thats how zoom uni feels like,

idk how other profs were, but this guy is very kind and knowledgeable
reviews.comment_grading:
10 MFL Homework (30%)
Midterm Exam (30%)
Final Exam (40%)

easy to get 100% for MFL, final and midterms are a bit tricky so dont be afraid to think outside the box, but i didnt like how we cant go through our mistakes in midterm then we never know where we went wrong, and i think its important for a technical subject like this, for this only i will downgrade the rating to B

i think i'll get B-B+ range, bit salty about how i cant go through my mid term exam for my mistakes, also cause i felt confident after my exam but it didnt turn out as i expected, final felt better and more fair, so maybe they took some of the emails under consideration
reviews.comment_workload:
the weekly MFL homework was a bit demanding considering they took a 3rd of your final grade, but overtime you get the hang of it and you can spend under 3 hours to get 100% score for all of these.

the final and mid term were a bit hard but again, i didn't prepare as much as i should have and kind of underestimated it, but its definitely doable considering you do everything right - make sure to use excel and review the MFL homework stuff it will do wonders

For me, I didn't join any tutorial sessions so I don't know if it is useful or not, but if you pay enough concentration during the lecture, I think is enough for you to understand all the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not easy to get good grades, as the professor said it is more like absolute grading, she said if you can get 90% or above overall, you must be able to get A range.

A. Class participation 7%
You need to do iprs questions during the lessons and sometimes you need to do questions in groups.

B. 11 MFL homework assignments (best 10) 15%
Each assignment each week, some are comparatively harder, but some are also really easy.

C. Online Quizzes (2) 3%
Each just weighs 1.5 %, the purpose of the quizzes is for revision.

D. Midterm Exam 35%
All MC. I would say the midterm exam is not really hard, I did all the practice questions from MFL, so I got high marks for the calculations part. But, I wasn't expecting there were conceptual questions, so I got low marks for the conceptual part. In the end, I got 79.8/100, the mean is 76.2 the median is 77.6, sd is 16.7

E. Final Exam 40%
All MC. I just did practice questions for the chapters which I think is hard and study a longer time for the note. In the end, I got 85%, the mean is 69.4, the median is 73.9, sd is 18.2

In the end, I got B, I was expecting B+, so quite disappointing.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not really high. There is only one assignment each week, which is questions from My Finance Lab. Each week one chapter, there won't be too many questions, at most 10, usually I would need about 1 hour to finish all the questions.

91.6/100 in Midterm (Mean: 75 SD: 13.5)
No scores were revealed for Quiz 2 and the final exam.

The workload is quite high.
It costs around 1-2 hours for each homework. It is because there was only 1 attempt before the midterm. After the midterm, it became 2 attempts. It is better to do similar questions in the study plan. Thus, it costs more time.

her English is good. however, her tone is tedious and without a lot of motivation. and she really likes to do the IPRS. because my lecture is at 9:00 so a lot of time I'm not so awake， therefore, I need to take extra time to review the content.
she emphasized the important content again and again. if you followed her, you can easily find what she would test in the final, almost all questions could be found in the slides. for example, the  
concepts of systematic risk and individual risk are very important and she said a lot of time in class, and they were tested a lot of times in the final.

grade: A+

reviews.author: SmallPotato02
reviews.title: Professor was very patient and willing to answer students' questions
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures + Tutorials
Time value of cash flows (Present Value, Future Value)
Bonds and Stocks valuation
Financial statements
Capital Budgeting
Risks and Return of financial actions
Cost of Capital
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor. SARKAR is very patient and willing to answer students' questions. He replied to the emails very quick such that students can carry on their revision without being stuck at a single question for too long. As for the tutorial sessions, the pace was quite fast but students could still learn from the explained sample questions. The overall teaching of the course was quite good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online Exercises 30%
Mid-term exam 30%
Final exam 40%

As the online exercises have unlimited attempts and the system showed the wrong answers, most students should have the full mark for the homework part.

For the mid-term exam. The tested content was quite manageable. But for the final exam, it was harder. Both exams were above mean but not too high.(Sorry for not remembering the scores) Final grade was B+.
reviews.comment_workload: The overall workload for this course was quite manageable because the exercises were just questions for financial calculations and concepts and about one exercise per week. As long as the slides were well understood and paid attention to the classes, everything would be fine. There were also tutorial sessions that talked about sample questions. Students could raise questions in these tutorials. Workload for mid-term was quite light because the covered chapters were quite solid and easy to understand. However, the final exam covered the last chapters which were harder to understand thoroughly. Thus, the workload to prepare for it was noticeably higher than that of mid-term. To conclude, the overall workload of the course was quite manageable but it was higher as the schedule proceeded.

Those powerpoint slides are clear and precise which also have many examples included for you to review. For some questions taught during the lecture, Emilio will explain the answer step by step and write it down for our references.

Mean: 70.8/100

reviews.author: jjm
reviews.title: Emilio is the Best Professor I've Had So Far
reviews.comment_content:
This is the content (in order):
- Chapter 1: Intro to Course, Intro to Corporate Finance
- Chapter 3: Time Value of Money: An introduction
- Chapter 4: Time Value of Money: Valuing Cash Flow Streams
- Chapter 5: Interest Rates (excluding 5.3)
- Chapter 8: Investment Decision Rules (exclude modified IRR in 8.3 and 8.6)
- Chapter 2: Review of Financial Statement Analysis (exclude 2.5-2.7)
- Chapter 9: Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting (exclude 9.5, 9.6, and MACRS).
- Chapter 9: Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting (exclude 9.5, 9.6, and MACRS)
- Chapter 6: Bonds Chapters 7, 10.1: Stock Valuation (exclude 7.6)
- Chapter 11: Risk and Return in Capital Markets
- Chapter 12: Systematic Risk and the Equity Premium
- Chapter 13: Cost of Capital (Apr 29); In-Class Final Preparation (May 4)

The beginning chapters are very easy to manage, but the content gets progressively harder. Overall, the content was highly interesting though and changed the way I personally observe the business world around me. I now know so many more finance concepts that are useful for everyday life and daily conversations.

Keep in mind, you do need to purchase a book (Pearson's Fundamentals of Corporate Finance) or at least an access code for the online version of the book and the online learning portal called My Finance Lab -> this is also where you have to submit your homework.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Emilio is the sweetest professor. He can teach well and he will make you feel welcome in class. Unfortunately many people in our class decided to turn off their cameras and don't interact at all, but those who did keep their cameras on and asked questions really formed a bit of a bond with him. He was always happy when people showed up and it made him sad when people turned off their cameras. Please turn on your cameras and ask questions, he loves the interaction!

Emilio always makes sure everyone is on the same page and spent lots of time explaining the basic concepts, in the beginning, to make sure people don't get lost further down the line in the course. He will always allow the opportunity to ask questions and will also provide helpful answers (the TA too, btw - make sure you take advantage of the TA when you're having trouble).
reviews.comment_grading:
Breakdown:
- 30% - 8 MyFinanceLab (MFL) Homework assignments
- 30% - Midterm exam
- 40% - Non-cumulative final exam

I always thought I did decent, did all my homeworks with 100% and scored above mean (midterm) and mean (final) for the exams, but final grade was a meagre B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Some might say the workload is very light because there are only eight homework assignments, but if you really want to understand all the content and score 100% on the homework assignments, you will be spending many many hours on MFL.

Pro tip: in the MFL system, you can find identical questions to those in your homework, just with different numbers. Practice on them first before tackling the homework questions which are graded.

reviews.comment_teaching:
It seems that it is the first time for professor Arkodipta, who is new to this university to teach this course.

He is really friendly and kind. Also very willing to answer questions from students.

Teaching quality is ok. Though the lecture focuses more on calculations rather than concepts. Read the textbook if you want to have a better understanding of course contents.

There are also tutorial sections (optional). That part simply demonstrates solutions to some questions. I think quality of tutorial is also acceptable.

30% MFL assignments

40% Final

Both exam shouldn't be any kind of challenge. I think most of the questions are easier than questions in MFL. Even though there will be one or two challenging questions that really requires you to have a clear understanding of contents, but they should be handleable.

Though, to achieve a good grade, it is necessary to spend time to complete most of the questions in the MFL study plan. That will be helpful for sure.

Tips to Ace the course: Learn how to use excel functions to do calculations as using excel is allowed in the exam. Try to create a template by yourself. That will be really helpful for sure.

reviews.comment_teaching:
She is a great professor, I like the way she uses examples to explain different financial concepts. There are a lot of exercises that she will explain in every lecture. She also uses a lot of PRS questions so you need to pay close attention when she is teaching.

There are tutorials every week although it is not compulsory.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is great, the quizzes are not hard as it doesn't matter anyway. Both exams are relatively easy just study from class exercises, MFL, and TAs.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is heavy. There are 10 MFL Homeworks, 2 Quizzes, 1 Mid-term, and 1 Final.

MFL Homeworks appears every week so you have to spare your weekend to finish them. In addition, you cannot make a single mistake as it only allows one attempt per question.

Attendance is required and you have to submit at least one (sometimes more) group exercise every class to earn participation points. Skipping lectures is not an option as it is also graded.

reviews.author: belowmeanguy
reviews.title: Good professor, not a bad course afterall

Weekly MyFinanceLab HWs are quite demanding imo. They are indeed very time-consuming as some are not easy questions, some are legit questions you will encounter in exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Clear PPT slides, I still suggested for more demonstration questions for each topics, (though it is quite impossible due to the packed course schedule)

Prof. Yan generally read from PPT slides, leave it for you to decide whether it's a good thing or not. PPT slides are clear and content is sufficient, so you don't have to worry if you skip lessons or you don't understand her English.

Quite sleepy though.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is perfectly fine from Prof. Yan, at least I'm satisfied with it. All my quizzes and mid-term are above mean, don't know the score for final yet. Got a B+ in the end. I think the grading make sense given that I'm not a top student.

Do work hard for this course, otherwise you will be very confused with the course materials, and you will be dead with the tricky questions.
reviews.comment_workload: For dumb students like me, just work hard and you will get a good grade in this course. Finish all MyFinanceLab Study Plan exercises, keep re-doing it until you are perfectly familiar with the questions. Question types in quizzes and exams are generally similar to those in MFL. So make sure you complete MFL exercises to get a full understanding of the course materials.

Chapter 1: Corporate Finance and the Financial Manager

reviews.comment_teaching: She is a good professor. She explains the concepts so clear and she is willing to answer you if you have any questions
reviews.comment_grading:
A. Class participation (10%)
Attend all the lectures and complete those breakout room exercises and iprs question would give you a solid 10.
B. 10 MFL homework assignments (best 9) (16%)
Each week you will have one homework. They are basically the same questions you can find from your textbook. So do practice a bit before you complete your homework since you would only have one attempt for each homework question.
C. 2 Online Quizzes (2% each)
There was only a few questions in each quiz, so no need to be nervous in those quizzes as it helps you to check your understandings
D. Midterm (30%)
Mean: 69/100, SD:15/100, Me:88/100
E. Final (40%)
Mean: 67/100, SD: 14/100, Me:74/100
Eventually, I got a B+ in this course because I didn't do well in my final. The grading is fair enough.
reviews.comment_workload: 10 MFL would give you a heavy workload because you need to spend lots of time to finish them every week. Also, there is so many people would like to have the finance major and it is quite competitive in order to have the A range.

reviews.author: why am I here

reviews.comment_content:
Mainly about different Finance concept.
Seems to be normal (not too hard not too easy)

This course covers:
Time Value of Money
FCF
Incremental Free Cash Flow
Bonds
Stocks
and many other stuffs. Usually just the extended part of the previous chapters. But it requires you to think very carefully otherwise you will get a wrong answer.

Just remind you that I think the financial calculator is a must of this course. Even though Professor Pi said we can use excel for that, I don't think that's a good idea as I am not good with that. The financial calculator is actually useful for 70% of the questions so is good to get one. However, it just become useless for me after this course and it is quite expensive.

She used thousands of examples in her lectures and you can see that she is really passionate in teaching. Her explanation is quite good. Just sometimes the question is too difficult.

Homework:

reviews.author: Heliumet
reviews.title: Fierce competition, a tough course
reviews.comment_content: Include basics of Finance which is useful for students especially with business major. Topics included such as the concept of time value of money, present and future value, discounted cashflow model, reading accounting statements, valuation of debentures and stocks etc. If you want to know more about rational decision making in the business world (or even personal finance), this is a good course for you.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is moderate, not particularly good or bad. She tries to explain things clearly and attract students to participate. Sometimes she can answer questions and doubts raised by students. One thing to note is that she is very reluctant towards paper-checking (I don't know what makes her so), which is negative towards students learning. She simply gives you marks of subtopics and ask you to revise those topics again. (until many students request paper-checking and finally she offers individual paper checking session with TA)
reviews.comment_grading:
10% class participation
4% quiz before exams (a total of 2, 2% each)
16% online assignment (approximately 8 - 11 assignment)
30% midterm
40% final

First, class participation is based on breakout room exercise done in lessons so you basically have some cost skipping them.

Second, online assignment is not as easy as other courses that might allow multiple attempts. Once you make it wrong, you lose the marks.

Third, midterm and final questions are not really very difficult in terms of calculations, but mostly conceptual or tricky. Competition is severe in this class as many students will strive to get good grades to declare a finance-related major. So make sure you are clear on concepts and be very careful in exams, otherwise you will be likely lie on or under the mean.
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate workload, no projects, but assignment and revision takes time. About one assignment per 1 - 2 weeks, and each takes around 30 - 60 mins doing it (depends on difficulty, usually those in the beginning is easier).

reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy workload.

But overall, practice makes perfect. Finishing all the MFL questions and understand them would yield A range.

reviews.author: Wolfheart
reviews.title: Ekkachai if you want to have a fun learning experience
reviews.comment_content:
Book:
Fundamentals of Corporate Finance, Global Edition, 4th Edition
By Jonathan Berk, Peter DeMarzo, Jarrad Harford

Syllabus (in order that was taught during class):
Chapter 1: Corporate Finance and the Financial Manager (excluding 1.2)
Chapter 3: Time Value of Money: An Introduction
Chapter 4: Time Value of Money: Valuing Cash Flow Streams Chapter 5: Interest Rates
Chapter 8: Investment Decision Rules (excluding MIRR)
Chapter 2: Financial Statement Analysis
Chapter 6: Bonds
Chapter 9: Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting (excluding 9.6 & MACRS)
Chapter 7: Stocks
Chapter 10: Stock Valuation: A Second Look
Chapter 11: Risk and Return in Capital Markets
Chapter 12: Systematic Risk and the Equity Risk Premium Chapter 13: Cost of Capital

Quiz covers Chapters 3-5; Midterm covers Chapters 1-5, 8; Final covers everything

Exams this semester are open-book so you can use Excel, OneNote, Acrobat, etc. No need for financial calculator. Exams consist of MCQs and fill-in-the-blank answers. For fill-in-the-blanks, answers must be correct to two decimal places so be very careful. Exams didn't really have time pressure so you can redo a question twice or thrice to make sure of the answer.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ekkachai is my funnest professor this semester.

The typical class is Ekkachai asking to turn on video, discussing news for about 10 minutes & making some relationships with contents from our syllabus (e.g. stocks and bonds), then cracking jokes (sometimes to the level of silly dad jokes lol) while teaching the day's lesson.

If you truly desire learning and want to have fun, reg Ekkachai. After all, it's all just fun and games until the exams roll around.

The T.A., Benson, wasn't really helpful aside from asking about anything related to the exam (e.g. stats), but he replies relatively quickly so that's nice.
reviews.comment_grading:
[5%] Quiz (mean = 8/10)
[15%] Assignments - MFL best 10 out of 11 assignments (unlimited attempts)
[35%] Midterm (mean = 20.8/28)
[45%] Final (mean = 25.8/40, SD = 7)

Scores:
Quiz: 10/10
Assignment: full
Midterm: 24/28
Final: 32/40

Scored B+ for the course. Tough luck since I tried hard in studying, prioritising this course over others. Grades for FINA 2303 are competitive and be advised that people taking it in spring are from Pathway 2 so they are more mathematically-talented and need the score for MSE (perhaps QFIN).
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly MFL isn't too difficult especially with unlimited attempts. In past years, I believe it was just 3 attempts per question. The disadvantage is that everyone probably received full marks for the 15% component. Just remember to set the deadlines in your calendar.

Preparation for the exams is the real scare - countless hours of MFL practice is a must and then possibly reading the book (Ekkachai advised to read the entire book at least once), although honestly lecture notes should suffice.

reviews.comment_workload: 10 MFL homework, and frequent revision is needed. Kind of tough and time-consuming but you may do the homework with your friends.

reviews.comment_teaching: The prof. teach very clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair.

final: didn't release the score

Grade: B-
reviews.comment_workload:
Little workload.

Only need to finish the online homework on time. There will be11 assignments, each pertaining to specific chapters in the textbook. One assignment with the lowest score will not be counted, and count only top 10 assignments. MFL Assignments will count for 15% of final grade in total.

There are two optional tutorial sessions in each week. TA will cover the same materials on Thursday and Monday. The tutorial notes will be uploaded on Canvas.

reviews.author: anonymous_stdn
reviews.comment_content: The content can be boring sometimes but the professor usually gives interesting real-world examples which help if you don't like to just learn the theory.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very slow in classes but usually, one lecture in a week is given through voice-over slides which can be skimmed through at a fast pace. He is also very organized so you always know how to prepare for classes.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is very strict and only if you get around 91% overall in the course do you stand a chance to get in A-range.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is decent: iPRS is taken every week, so might be necessary to read the textbook and finish voice-over slides every week because iPRS marks matter in final grade.

reviews.author: Ahaan
reviews.title: Need constant practice
reviews.comment_content: Pretty good content starting from various kinds of ratios in finance world to understanding the three sides to finance.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is a bit slow in his lectures which required previous study before each one of them. He provides mock papers before each exam to let you know the pattern.
reviews.comment_grading: With two midterms and one final, five homeworks and 10 iprs, I would say that someone near the mean would definitely be in the B range like me.
reviews.comment_workload: Constant workload but easy, it would far more easier for students who are good at mathematics and do not find it tough to do severe calculations. Overall a pretty easy course, you just need to have confidence and it'll be your way.

reviews.author: nickname user
reviews.comment_content:
Covers selective parts of the textbook you HAVE to purchase: Corporate Finance: Core principles and application.  

If you havent had any background with finance, be sure to read the textbook and practice more, especially concepts.

Basic financial knowledge content:
- Cash Flow
- Time value of money
- Interest rates
- Bond Valuation
- Stock Valuation
- Net Present Value
- Capital Budgeting, Risk and return
-etc.

IPRS EVERY SINGLE LESSON, he counts the top 8 scores of your IPRS. the questions will appear on his exams so need to go through: even the ones with lots of specific numbers. after you have 8 full scores then you can stop going to the lessons LOL cus the lessons are quite boring
IPRS is easy to  get full score if you do reading before lesson

homeweek assignments throughout semester: Connect system keeps top 4/5
2 midterms 1 final, all can bring cheatsheet double sided a4 which is pretty good.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Peter is actually a nice guy, he is quite friendly and likes to answer your questions, if you express your need for more time for an assignment he usually gives you more time.
BUT its peter's first time teaching this course so he doesnt seem to be VERY familiar with the content. THere has been multiple times when students ask him questions and his answer did not help at all or he just couldn't give a reason to justify it.
He really emphasizes on teaching with the blended learning mode which is basically YOU as students learn the content yourself and instead of having class twice a week, you only attend once and listen to his somewhat irrelevant ppts and copy the answers on a worksheet he gives you. and then every lesson ends with an IPRS.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is pretty good, mean for everything is pretty reasonable. Sometimes the grade changes because something might be wrong with the questions, if you get lucky then you'll get higher score.
reviews.comment_workload: reading every week and work on the online Connect system homework. need to make time to read AND go to lesson pretty annoying but not too bad still manageable. Prepare to use more time to read because you're basically learning everything by yourself. Add oil

reviews.author: pdine
reviews.comment_content: Mr. Mackay mainly uses the book for teaching although, he does include material from his PPT slides in the final exam. Although the content is necessarily difficult, it is difficult to find practice problems from the book to review for the exams. This is because the prof doesn't teach the entire chapter only parts of it as a result, not all the problems at the back of the book are applicable.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. Mackay's teaching was average at best. I certainly believed that he could have provided more revision material, especially for the trickier chapters.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was similar to the other FINA classes with the mean grade hovering between B and B-.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was very manageable and I don't think any student will find it difficult to manage.

reviews.author: Freeds
reviews.title: good course but competitive
reviews.comment_content: interesting content, give you a basic understanding of cooperate finance.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Peter adopted blended-learning method, which means there are one in-class course and one online course with PPT and recording. The teaching material is generally well-prepared, with some small mistakes and confusions. His in-class teaching is a little boring because of the slow speaking speed and the flat voice.

Personally, I think Peter is a responsible and patient teacher. he is always willing to help when students have problems to ask. he also welcomes feedback to improve his teaching. however, he made mistakes on his exam questions very frequently and didn't amend them during the exam, which troubled us a lot, and is also not fair for those who worked hard and wanted to get good mark.

His TA, Vincent, is also a very responsible and nice person, always being helpful.
reviews.comment_grading: the class is very competitive, so everybody got quite high in midterms and finals. if you want to get A range you need to be careful with every graded task and try to lose as few points as you can.
reviews.comment_workload: 5 homework, 2 midterms, 1 final, the workload given by the professor is not too heavy. but if you didn't learn finance before, you need to spend more time on it after class.

reviews.author: Jenny Wu
reviews.comment_content: Intended as an introductory course to corporate finance, I found the content relatively manageable. Topics include financial statement analysis, time value of money, bond and stock valuation, capital budgeting, risk and return concepts and cost of capital. It provided a good starting point for students who didn't have a background in finance.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Mackay speaks in a monotone during lectures, so it is really a challenge to stay awake sometimes in his class sometimes.  He also tends to digress a bit when he elaborates on some topics. Though it provides good real-life context to the topics, it is sometimes deemed inefficient by students who just want to do well in tests. Despite speaking in a monotone, he provides very good notes/ppts. They are concise and visual, which makes them particularly effective for self-studying and the synthesis of different equations/concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is transparent and fair. There are a total of 5 assessment methods:

1. 12 In-class activities (ICA) (keep top 8/12) 16% - basically there will be an ICA every week (exact dates will be on the syllabus). During each ICA, there will be an iPRS quiz of 4-5 questions, each question will be out of 2 marks, 1 for participation, the other for the correctness. Grades for each ICA will be out by the end of that week.

2. 5 Homework Assignments (on connect system, keep top 4/5) 16% - questions are usually pretty standard and are all in the textbook

*3. 1st midterm (MC) 20% – Median: 22/30, Mean: 21.58/30, SD: 4.09

*4. 2nd Midterm (MC) 18% – Median: 23, Mean 22.4, SD: 4.55

*5. Final Exam (MC, cumulative content) 30% – Mean: 36.45, SD:5.28

*One double-sided (A4) Cheatsheet allowed (can be digital and/or handwritten)

The mean is usually kept within 70-80% Prof Mackay's class, which is not too high. If you put in an adequate amount of time to study & thoroughly understand the concepts, do some PQ from the textbook, and complete all the mock papers that the prof provides before every midterm/exam you're pretty much set for all his tests.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course mainly just consists of (bi-weekly) homework assignments and studying. Although you will have to keep up with that week's material when there is an iPRS quiz, the general workload is more manageable than other business courses that have group projects and reports in addition to midterms and a final exam.

reviews.author: s5348
reviews.comment_content:
This course introduces basic concepts of corporate finance to students.

- Introduction to Corporate Finance
- Financial Statements & Cash Flow
- Financial Statement Analysis & Financial Models
- Discounted Cash Flow Valuation
- Interest Rates and Bond Valuation
- Stock Valuation
- Net Present Value and Other Investment Rules
- Making Capital Investment Decisions
- Return and Risk: The Capital Asset Pricing Model
- Risk, Cost of Capital, and Capital Budgeting
reviews.comment_teaching:
It is a blended-learning course, which basically means you need to learn everything by yourself.
You only attend one class per week but you need to go over VOS slides in your own time.This will be uploaded every week on Canvas before the class.

During the lecture, the professor didn't taught much but spent time on IPRS and in-class activities; the attendance was taken by IPRS.

Reconsider the instructor unless you are confident with self-learning for the whole course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment: Weight

12 In-Class Activities (keep top 8/12): 16%
5 Homework Assignments (keep top 4/5): 16%
1st Midterm Exam: 20%
2nd Midterm Exam: 18%
Final Exam: 30%

All exam questions were multiple-choice and it was allowed to bring one cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not too heavy:

- In-Class Activities and IPRS
-  5 online homework assignments
  (It will be not too difficult to complete if you do practice questions on the textbook)
- 2 Mid-term exams
- Final exam

reviews.author: Harson Lin
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content: This course is about basic corporate finance, including some really fundamental but useful tools such as ratio analysis, discounted stock and bond pricing, WACC, DCF model, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Ekkachai is one of the best instructors I have met in UST. Although he speaks English in his Thai accent, it's not hard to recognize. He is humorous and funny when introducing finance ideas and sometimes would merge some market news into the course if he has time. Make sure you get to the class earlier - you always have to compete for seats with your classmates
reviews.comment_grading:
Neutral. But the course is generally easy, just spend some time and you'll get good grades.

Midterm 1 20%
Midterm 2 20%
Final 43%
IPRS attendence 2%
Homework 15%

Be careful with the homework and you can get full marks.

He does not take attendance every class, and usually will notify you when he's planning to take it the next class. You need to answer correctly 10 questions for the entire sem to get the full 2%, do not worry cuz he'll ask far more questions than that. And to be honest, 2% is negligible even if you miss it.

2 midterms and final are generally in the same difficulty, didn't feel that final is harder than midterms
reviews.comment_workload: One online homework per week to evaluate your learnings. I think the workload is just appropriate.

reviews.author: justforfun
reviews.comment_content: Mainly focuses on calculations. Most of the formulae can be found in the powerpoint while you may need to attend the tutorials to understand how to use those formulae. A formula sheet will be provided in the final exam, meaning that you don't need to memorize every formula by yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching:
blended- learning mode.
Every week the professors will upload a VOS(a powerpoint with his voice explaining each slide) for your self study. It is a good way for learning. You can listen to the VOS whenever you want to make sure you are fully focused. Every VOS is about 40-50 mins which is shorter than the traditional classes.
You only need to attend one class every week in which the professor will focus on in-class activity(ICA) which is a disaster in this course. I will say only a small amount of people can understand what is really going on in the ICAs.
reviews.comment_grading:
- HW  16% (keep top 4 out of 5)
- iPRS  16% (keep top 8 out of 12, in which 3 of them are mock exams, you can get full mark for those 3 mock exams as long as you answer all the iPRS questions, no matter you answer them correctly or not)
- mid-term 1  20%
- mid-term 2  18%
- final exam  30%

The exams were all MC. You can have a cheat sheet for every exam.

According to the professor, between upper-quartile and lower-quartile will be in the B range which is quite fair.
However, there were a number of error in the mid-term 1 and final paper. Also, the ICA questions in the final exam were just a direct copy from the previous mock exams. These two factors increased the mean score a lot. You have to make lots of efforts or even by luck to have an A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
- 5 easy HWs
- iPRS after each ICA
- 2 mid-terms
- 1 final
They can be easily managed.

reviews.comment_content:
Very funny and comfortable professor and unlike many other professors he actually says hi and stays for a chat if you meet him outside the classroom. Not only is his teaching very good, but he also looks very good. If you’re into guys and you need an extra motivation to attend classes: choose Emilio!

reviews.comment_teaching: Emilio has a very western way of teaching. He speaks loud and clear as well as having some funny jokes here and there. He explains the concepts very well, and gives us the time to complete some practice questions during class. He also listens to students preferences in terms of exams and homework.
reviews.comment_grading: Very kind with grading as you’re given partial credit on the midterm. For the final it’s multiple choices, and the mean is here a bit lower than on the midterm. If you do his practice questions you should be well prepared for the exams, however the exams are a bit more complicated. In our year the midterm was quite easy but the final was a lot harder.
reviews.comment_workload: As finance generally has a high workload, Emilio doesn’t give too much work. He gives homework on myfinance lab weekly, but that’s it.

The things he mentioned in class seldom appeared in the quiz and exams. Self-learning is important. You have to read the textbook and do a lot of online materials to teach yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: It's a competitive course as everyone wants to have an finance major. There's iPRS in most of the lecture so you have to be attending every lecture
reviews.comment_workload: Terrifying. A lot of practices and MFL quiz every week. Each quiz will take you hours to finish, let alone you'll have to retake the quiz when you do not pass the 80% mark.

reviews.author: Game King
reviews.title: Good intro course to Fina
reviews.comment_content:
"This class is designed to give you an understanding of the fundamentals of corporate finance. Topics include financial statement analysis, time value of money, capital budgeting, cost of capital, risk and return. At the end of the course, you will be able to evaluate the profitability of a project, and value financial products such as stocks and bonds."

The content is easy and suitable for the students who want to take QFIN,FINA and ECOF as their majors. It gives you an overall look in finance and the fundamentals. Most of the topics require math and calculation, but they are clear and easy to follow.

reviews.author: i am groot
reviews.title: He had no idea what teaching was...
reviews.comment_teaching:
I really think the professor is good at finance, but not really good at teaching. The way he spoke was not attractive as his has an Indian accent.
He often uses real life cases to demonstrate some basic finance concepts. I like the way he istrying to be practical, but most of the time real life cases are complicated that amateurs cannot instantly follow and understand the big picture. Plus he always uses abbreviations, which just make the whole thing more confusing.

reviews.author: jybt
reviews.title: Fair grading based on your own efforts
reviews.comment_content:
Important content on financial concepts that encompass time value of money, stock and bond pricing, risk and volatility and capital budgeting among others. These are relatively understandable in class, but regular revision is recommended (even mandatory to get good grades, and by good I mean B+ or A range) on the online MyLab Finance platform (where she will give you homework questions).

Do questions beyond the required homework questions and practice as many questions as you can so that you can understand more complicated questions and calculations. The formulas are not that difficult to understand, but make sure you understand how to apply them in the word problems that Veronique likes to ask.

TIP: Definitely read the textbook, which I find much more helpful in explaining the concepts than simply going to class.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Veronique goes through the slides very quickly, so you will have to pay attention to be able to understand the IPRS questions that she has. She uses real world examples, but can end up being a little monotone. Nevertheless, she is still a very kind lady who will answer your questions (if you have any) at the end of class.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading, but competitive. If you put additional effort into it (e.g. doing MyLab Finance regularly and reading the textbooks), you should get at least a B+. Midterms and final exam are worth a lot, and are in a multiple choice format similar to the IPRS in class (but with higher complexity). There are 2 online quizzes which are not worth very much, and are also in multiple choice. Participation is calculated using the IPRS, so you should attend class.
reviews.comment_workload: To be honest, the workload is not so light if you want to get a B at the least. The exams are cumulative, and therefore they cover a lot of content. There is homework from the MyLab Finance platform every week (the answers are basically given to you from the examples), but you should spend more time on this to revise for exams (without looking at any of the given examples).

reviews.author: PPBBB
reviews.title: Good grade if you work hard
reviews.comment_content:
Exams are cumulative so you have to revise the course materials throughout the term. The contents are confined by the department so changes of contents are not likely.
The course required some statistical background. Having basic accounting knowledge is preferred.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A lot of examples are given in the lecture notes. Although some may think her notes are too long and tedious due to tons of examples, these help you better understand the topics.
The professor is very kind to help students and TA is always there to answer students' questions before and after classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair, based on how much you work on the course.
The following is the grading policy:
Participation (in terms of iPRS) [4%]
2 online quizzes [6%]
My Finance Lab HW (choose the best 9 out of 10) [15%]
Mid term [30%]
Final [45%]
Notes:
1. You will never know how you behave in class (i.e. no grades will be released based on the participation)
2. The online quizzes were relatively easy compared with exams. (At least I got 100% for both quizzes)
3. The Homework in MFL is compulsory for the course so you need to purchase the text-book.
4. I got all 10 HWs 100% and they can be practised through the study plan so you should be able to get 15% for the final grade easily.
5. Mid term was very difficult while Final was relatively easy.
6. All questions in this course are MCs or T/F.
reviews.comment_workload:
As told, the final grade depends on how much you spend on the courses, including but not limited to, your time and efforts.
You are advised to attend class in order to keep yourself on track.
