reviews.author: zcachuang
reviews.title: An introductory course into finance
reviews.comment_content: FINA 2303 is an introductory course into the finance field. It mainly talks about the time value of money, interest rate, bond market, stock valuation and risk and return. Some valuation models learned in this course, such as DDM, DFCFM, CAPM, are useful in the valuation of a corporation and stock. However, it is a theoretical course whose contents may not be practical into the real market. Most of the contents are conceptual and requires a little calculation. A financial calculator will be helpful to your calculations.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is a big class. The professor uses ppt to teach. The ppt is in great detail with some questions that are of typical kind. The professor proceeds with the ppt at a bit fast speed, so you will easily get lost if you have not done the preview. The class may be a little boring. However, professor will use some real world cases to improve our sense of finance. Besides, Veronique is really a great professor! She is really cute!!! You will find it out if you attend her lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair. It contains mid-term, final, 10 online assignments (which you will need an access code together with the textbook), 2 online quizzes and in-class participation. Of all the assessments, the midterm and final exams are really important. Although they are all multiple choice questions, they are not easy to be dealt with if you are not familiar with the lecture content. The in-class participation with be carried out by IPRS. No matter you answer the question right or wrong, you will get the score. But you have to attend each lecture.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is a little bit huge. And I strongly suggest that you do the review on a routine basis. It's impossible that you will go through the contents in the last minute.

reviews.comment_grading: Fair, above more than 1 standard deviation in midterm, but only 0.4 standard deviation in final, so got B+ eventually
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy, would get full mark in assignments as long as you've worked on it. The project was not tough. Exams were all multiple choices.

reviews.author: karen lam
reviews.comment_content: There are quite a lot of content covered in this course, and attendance are needed every lesson, so it is not recommended to skip class. For the midterm and final, conceptual questions are hard than the numerical ones. There is also about 6 to 7 challenging questions. Time is adequate for the exams in my point of view, and it is suggested to finish all the numerical questions first.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Pi is a very cheerful professor who is always willing to chat and solve questions with students. Her TA Michael is also a very awesome teacher who really could explain how the problems can be done in a very detailed way. So if there is any misunderstandings in lecture, go to the tutorial! 2 participation cards are needed to fulfil participation marks.
reviews.comment_grading: I got an A- with both midterm and final marks above almost 1s.d. And all homework 95% full mark. To get good grades, do the study plan as practices.
reviews.comment_workload: There is online homework that includes in the course that dues every week. So you have to be careful on missing any homework because they are 15% of the course grade. There is one midterm one final, and the exam type is all MC questions.

reviews.author: ychan
reviews.comment_content:
Course Syllabus:
Chapter 1: Corporate Finance and the Financial Manager (exclude 1.2)
Chapter 3: Time Value of Money: An Introduction
Chapter 4: Time Value of Money: Valuing Cash Flow Streams
Chapter 5: Interest Rates (exclude 5.3)
Chapter 8: Investment Decision Rules (exclude Modified IRR in 8.3, and 8.6)
Chapter 2: Introduction to Financial Statement Analysis (exclude 2.5)
Midterm exam (chapters 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8)
Chapter 9: Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting (exclude MACRS in 9.4, 9.5, and 9.6)
Chapter 6: Bonds
Chapter 7: Stocks
Chapter 10: Stock Valuation: A Second Look (exclude 10.4 and 10.5)
Chapter 11: Risk and Return in Capital Markets
Chapter 12: Systematic Risk and the Equity Risk Premium
Chapter 13: Cost of Capital

Some chapters are quite challenging such as the Chapter 8 and 9. It is very important to understand the concept of time value of money.
reviews.comment_teaching: The overall learning experience is fine but the professors cannot explain some difficult concepts very clearly. It is important to do more exercises and read the textbook to catch up the teaching progress.
reviews.comment_grading:
A. Class participation (10%)
B. MFL Homework assignments (15%)
C. Midterm Exam (30%)
D.     Final Exam (45%)

The prof does not specify marking scheme of the class participation. It includes iPRS, TAPPS (in-class group discussion questions) and participation cards.
The professor only requires students to get two cards for the whole semester. Answers will be provided in class, so the class participation mark is not really hard to get.

The grading system is quite fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is normal.

The MFL homework assignments are quite time-consuming. But there are similar questions for your reference. Just make sure you spare some time for those questions.

Both mid-term and final exam are MC questions.
The final exam is cumulative. The professor provides the questions distribution for reference for both exams.

reviews.author: Helennn
reviews.title: Good professor, reg for his course if you are interested in finance
reviews.comment_content: The content is very straight forward and easy to understand by using daily life examples. When you feel confused, you can just refer to textbooks. The professor has recommended some MyFinanceLab exercises for each chapter, by doing all these can guarantee you a good result in all exams. Remember to do tutorials questions also.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very hilarious and it is fun to attend his lectures, many students from other lectures would also like to attend his lectures. He always provides a lot of daily life examples and exercises in his lecture notes to help you understand. He don't mind if you don't understand a certain topic, he would let you to discuss with your friends or explain it again to you:)
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good. Make sure to attend the lectures to  do iPRS questions for participation marks and do homeworks on time. Doing MFL exercises is important since it helps you to understand the topic, don't just do it without understanding it.

The mean was quite high, maybe because many students wanted to select finance as major. But if you do enough exercises and understand the topics thoroughly, you won't need to worry about it.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light, only one mid-term exam, quiz and final exam. There are 10 homework assignments on MyFinanceLab, the professor sometimes would post the homeworks without announcements, so you should always log in to MFL to check if there is any homework.

reviews.author: sabrinacc
reviews.title: short review
reviews.comment_content: covers some basic concepts in finance e.g. bonds, stocks, time value of money. all these are easily to understand and learn
reviews.comment_teaching: teach from the slides. little extra knowledge taught in class. for those who eager to learn more, Professor Pl Lynn is not a good choice
reviews.comment_grading:
exams are doable since they are more or less similar to MFL and the ppt slides.
As long as you have studied the ppt slides well, we can get around 85% of the exam.

Class participation 10%(PRS + 3 cards)
MFL Homework assignments 15%
Midterm Exam 30%
Final Exam 45%
reviews.comment_workload:
light workload.
No quiz. For professor Ekkachai, there are quizzes after he finished teaching 1 chapter.  
Just need to finish MFL every week.
Do the PRS and TAPPS every lesson

reviews.author: ShoW
reviews.comment_content: Covers the basic concepts in finance such as time value of money, bond/stock pricing, Important if you want a finance major as this course will determine your legibility for a major in finance.
reviews.comment_teaching: I've heard people say that her teaching is useless and that just reading the slides at home is enough. However, she is not as bad as people say she is; her explanations were easy to understand for me.
reviews.comment_grading:
I actually think the exams are doable as long as you pay attention in class and do the MFLs (I didn't do the extra MFLs which are just for practice). I do not know how better other classes might be content-wise, but her exam mostly sticks to the slides.

A. Class participation 10% - PRS + 3 cards
B. MFL Homework assignments 15%
C. Midterm Exam 30%
D. Final Exam 45%
reviews.comment_workload: I would say that the workload is comparatively light if you are clear with the concepts; and professor PI Lynn has no quizzes unlike professor Ekkachai, and this felt like a plus to me. Only have to get the 3 participation cards, do the PRS in class and do MFLs, study the slides before exam.

reviews.author: Avocado
reviews.title: Workload depends on the grade you want.
reviews.comment_content:
The content is well organised and refers directly to the textbook, so it's quite straightforward to reference between the two. Since it's an introductory finance course, some of the more advanced topics in the chapters are occasionally skipped.

Course contents include financial statement analysis, time value of money, interest rates, bonds, stocks, investment decision rules, fundamentals of capital budgeting, risk and return, equity risk premium, and WACC.

Lecture slides are posted for each topic, and the answers to all the in-class exercises are also provided for revision.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Pi is a good teacher and she explains all the concepts very clearly to students during lectures. Her lecture slides and teaching are very organised and based of the textbook, so it's pretty straightforward to follow through. The TA is also really helpful, and weekly tutorials are held where the TA goes through and solves some example problems from each chapter.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is relatively fair.

There are four components which contribute to the final grade: class participation (10%), MFL homework assignments (15%), midterm exam (30%), final exam (45%).

There are 10 homework assignments to be completed during the course (very useful to do these because firstly they contribute to your grade, and secondly, it's good practice for the exams).

Midterm and final exam have three components - conceptual questions, numerical questions, and challenging questions.

The midterm exam mean was 73/100 with SD 13, and final exam mean was 72/115 with SD 17.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload really depends on the grade you want in this course. If you want a good grade, you have to invest a lot of time in solving all the problems on MFL and going through all the course content carefully. However, if you just want to pass, the workload should be lighter I suppose.

reviews.author: Joyce
reviews.comment_content: The content is not difficult mainly are discounting cash flows and study some basic model like CAPM. Also financial calculator is a must for this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: His class is quite interesting and he explains the ideas and concepts clearly in class.
reviews.comment_grading: Not good as lots of students achieve very high marks. So try to get as high marks as you can in everything including participation and assignments.
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy as only online assignments, 2 midterms and final. Also you have to participate in class by either answering questions or prs.

reviews.author: VIRose
reviews.comment_content: As other reviews, quite useful, intuitive content.
reviews.comment_teaching: He taught quite good, extended to a lot of additional knowledge, some people may dislike it as they don't relate to exams. However his voice is quite low, which makes me sleepy all the time.
reviews.comment_grading: Not bad, I have finished all the online quizzes which are not difficult, as you can do unlimited times and spend a day doing the project seriously, read the textbook thoroughly I got a B+. I didn't go to class after I answered the assigned question once, and went to no tutorials.
reviews.comment_workload: There are some workload: one pop up in class question per person, online quizzes (all sessions need to do it tho), a project, mid-term, final.

reviews.author: Tiffanyho
reviews.comment_content: It contains a lot of basic knowledge of Corporate Finance. It is quite difficult for people who don't know anything about Finance before. This course covers many topics.
reviews.comment_teaching: His lecture is very informative and useful as he talks a lot about the financial market and many extra information. But he is relatively speaking too fast.
reviews.comment_grading: the mean is very high in this course. you have to get almost full mark to get an A
reviews.comment_workload: workload is fair. there is online assignment every two weeks and one easy case study.

reviews.author: bb
reviews.comment_content: Personally I think the content was slightly difficult, and there was lots of theories. I think MK Lai focused on theories instead of application and calculation.
reviews.comment_teaching: MK Lai's teaching style is super super fast which I could barely catch up. Sometimes he did not explain concepts very deeply, especially for formulas.
reviews.comment_grading: Mid-term and final included MC only, but those questions were quite difficult, lots of students got only half of the paper correct in final. But grading was quite fair and reasonable.
reviews.comment_workload: Group case study consisted of around 10 questions, the workload was acceptable (unless your group mate free ride). But the content of PPT was huge, studying for exams may required more efforts.

reviews.author: mkma
reviews.comment_content: The content is mainly related to some fundamental financial theories and concepts. The textbook is a good reference if you find any difficulty in your study. However, most parts related to US market are not required in the exam, so you should focus more on HK market.
reviews.comment_teaching: At first, you might feel difficult to adapt to MK Lai 's teaching as his pace is very fast. Still, you need to jot down a lot of things during the lecture as those could be tested in exam. MK Lai is such a passionate and nice professor that he is willing to answer all kinds of questions in detail and will organize extra lesson to help students with their study,
reviews.comment_grading: It is easy to score well for the projects. For the exam, midterm one is fine. But the final exam is relatively difficult and consists of some tricky questions. The grading is quite good in my opinion.
reviews.comment_workload: 2 projects, 1 midterm, 1 final exam plus one question as participation throughout the whole semester. I think it is fine.

reviews.author: ft
reviews.comment_content: The content is related to Hong Kong context.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. sometimes forgot where he stopped last time as the progress of his three sections were different.
He spoke so fast that nobody understands what he was talking about.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% participation
10% Case 1
15% Case 2
35% Midterm
35% Final
reviews.comment_workload:
Participation: 上堂抽人答問題，答中full mark, 答錯可能有少少分(仲有第2 round有機會拎返分), 唔答即係冇上堂就0分
Case study x2:
自己分組, 我既groupmates全部唔做野所以對我黎講超大workload

reviews.author: HEHE
reviews.comment_content:
Basic financial concepts like time value of money, stock and bonds valuation.
Unlike Ekkachai's sessions, Prof. Lai added some CFA content in his teaching which means his teaching is not the same as the textbook and students are recommended to attend his lectures.
Both midterm and final exam are mc questions and non-cumulative.
Prof. Lai has prepared a name list for asking each student one question for participation or attendance mark that is same as Fina1303. Once you answer the question correctly, you can get 5% of your overall course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The two project cases can let students learn a lot and clear some financial concepts, especially for case 2, that is a good teaching method I think.
reviews.comment_grading: Same grade distribution as Ekkachai's sessions.
reviews.comment_workload: It depends on your project groupmates.

reviews.comment_content: Super many calculations. Things about stock, bond etc. Need to calculate time value of money (which i always get them wrong)
reviews.comment_teaching: Ekkachai's voice is very cute. Overall teaching is quite good but when it comes to limited time, he may rush through slides and ask students to go home and read them  by themselves.
reviews.comment_grading: Poor grades. Heard that A is 95% sth and B is 85% sth.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite heavy. over 10 online assignments (abt 30th questions) throughout the whole semester. Reading through txtbook takes much time already, not to mention doing calculation exercise. another thing is to get used to using financial cal.

reviews.title: FINA 2303
reviews.comment_content:
time value of money, bonds, stocks, cash flow of capital, etc
全部都係好basic上的野 無講到好入
reviews.comment_teaching:
ekkachai教學唔錯
雖然係雞仔聲
但起碼佢上堂係理論上同實際應用上都會講
又會有不時講D financial news同埋上堂做個d題目
當然都可以去埋tutorial問TA啦

reviews.author: walalalala
reviews.title: Good grade course, thx Emilio!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic concept for time value of money, cash flows and risk of portfolios

reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is good and the prof is somehow funny. He presented the concepts very well and the TA is also nice to help.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think it’s good, esp the course is highly competitive when most students are from pathway 2.

Midterm:
Mean: 25.45/31

SD: 3.84

Final results are not released
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is still manageable, there are 8 hw in total, midterm and final. The questions are not that hard, you can easily refer to the ppts. Final is much harder than midterms, probably with the concepts from accounting courses. No attendance is required

reviews.author: 爆4 please
reviews.title: Hard work pays off
reviews.comment_content:
1. Financial Statement Analysis
2. Time Value of Money (Present value, future value, perpetuity, annuity)
3. Interest Rates
4. Bonds
5. Stock Valuation
6. Investment Decision Rules
7. Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting

9. Risk and Return in Capital Markets
10. Systematic Risk and the Equity Risk Premium
11. The Cost of Capital
reviews.comment_teaching: Goyal's content was more challenging than other professors, but it will be ok if you pay attention in class. He is also willing to answer students' questions, so feel free to ask him after class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 5%
Home Work 10% (Only the 4 best homework assignments were counted)
Midterm 30%
Quiz 10%
Final 45%

Class participation: 4/4 (mean 3.14)
Homework: 58.75/60
Midterm: 82/100 (mean 67.96)
Quiz: 65/100 (mean 63.9)
Final: didn't release marks
Final grade: A-

You can definitely score high by finishing all the chapter quizzes and practices given by the prof. There were tutorials but attendance was not needed. I do not recommend attending them because you won't be able to understand anyway. It will be more effective to go through the tutorial materials by yourself. Also, don't hesitate to ask the TA and prof about the exercises and maybe homework as well.
reviews.comment_workload: A bit high at the beginning since the homework assignments were timed. However, after the midterm, he listened to students' feedback and cancelled the time limit, so we had around 5-6 days to finish the homework.

reviews.author: k14n
reviews.comment_content:
1. financial statement analysis
2. valuation (time value of money, perpetuities, annuities)
3. bonds
4. stocks
5. NPV rule and creation of value (investment decision rules, NPV vs IRR)
6. project evaluation
7. cost of equity, cost of debt, cost of capital (CAPM)
reviews.comment_teaching: 口音問題 有時會聽唔明 不過好彩有recording recap 重複又重複聽囉要
reviews.comment_grading: Final 考得唔好 但神奇地算靚grade
reviews.comment_workload: myfinace lab 好多條 好多野 又複雜 所以後尾幾課幾乎放棄咁滯

reviews.author: PeggyHui
reviews.title: Nice prof
reviews.comment_content:
1. financial statement analysis
2. valuation (time value of money, perpetuities, annuities)
3. bonds
4. stocks
5. NPV rule and creation of value (investment decision rules, NPV vs IRR)
6. project evaluation
7. cost of equity, cost of debt, cost of capital (CAPM)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is very knowledgeable so he can really explain the concept in great detail. I was a bit scared of Finance at the very beginning, but he did a really great job in explaining everything with simple but effective examples. He made Finance something that's enjoyable.

Also, he took the suggestions of students seriously. When people asked for more practice questions, he printed them out. Really amazing teacher. The resources on Canvas provided by him is more than adequate and very useful.

The TA is super nice as well. He always replies to emails swiftly and explains things in a professional manner.
reviews.comment_grading:
MT: 98/100 (mean should be around 70?)
Final 82/100 (can't remember the mean but highest is 86)
MFL: 19.996/20
Attendance: 5/5
Final Grade: A+

with IPRS for attendance
reviews.comment_workload:
the most troubling part is MFL. I did not quite understand how the system worked and thus lost some marks. So do make sure you spent a decent amount of time exploring the system. Furthermore, it is sooooooooo time consuming to complete. You need to spend around one afternoon+evening, or sometimes one afternoon + evening +morning to complete the homework. The system is also designed in a painstakingly horrible way that can drive people crazy and give you a heart attack. No that the questions are hard, but the system.../facepalmed/ This thing is too horrendous to exist on earth.

while for the content, they are pretty fundamental and easy. As long as you pay attention during the lecture and ask when you do not understand, you do not need to spend much time revising after class or even before exams.

In short, 1) MFL is a nightmare 2) always ask prof/TA if you are confused 3) do not need much after lecture revision

reviews.author: heyhihere
reviews.title: I love Goyal
reviews.comment_content: I guess other comments have already gave a brief introduction for the content part and so I’m not repeating.
reviews.comment_teaching: GOYAL is a good professor, not much to mention. He is willing to listen to our comments and make adjustments.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think it’s good enough, FINA classes are really competitive and it’s quite difficult to get a b range grade but luckily I got a B+

overall ~79%
reviews.comment_workload: Only six MFL exercise. Some questions are really hard to do but you can try some in the study plan and which can guarantee a full mark in your 20% MFL exercise.

reviews.comment_teaching: Goyal pays a lot of effort to teach. He will try to explain many concepts with daily examples. But, you have to be familiar with these examples before so that you can understand them. He will ask what we want, e.g., he was asked to provide the class with more exercises. He will try to fulfill all our needs. Although he pays a lot of effort and passion, some lectures are actually quite boring. He will give different students many opportunities to answer the in-class exercises so that everyone has a chance to attempt the question. He explains the questions in detail so that you will be able to understand how to deal with similar questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
A. Six homework assignments (20%)
B. Class Participation (5%)
C. Midterm Exam (35%)
D. Final Exam (40%)
reviews.comment_workload: It is not a heavy workload as there are just six MFL assignments. But each MFL is time-consuming if you aim to get a high or even full marks. Goyal will distribute exercises to let us be familiar with the final exam. He will ask you to do it before the lesson, but he will give you time to do it during the lecture. The exams cover a lot of content. Although some are simple, you have to remember the equations that the exam paper did not give. You can get a better grade in this course if you pay more effort.

reviews.author: Tabitha
reviews.comment_content: It's the basis of FINA so that the content isn't very difficult,but the prof explained it in a difficult way, which made it hard to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof used many different ways to make to lecture easier to understand such as PRS or pdf sharing. But I have to say it only added to our burden and served no purpose. It also prevents us from focusing on the lecture itself.
reviews.comment_grading: The grades are made up of midterm, final, quiz and homework. The prof always say that there will be some bonus point, but I'm not sure about it.

reviews.author: suikanano
reviews.title: Ask TA and you will succeed
reviews.comment_content:
Week2: Time Value of Money
Week 3: Interest Rates
Weeks 3 and 4: Investment Decision Rules
Week 5: Financial Statement Analysis
Week 6: Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting
Week 7: Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting Continued
Week 8: Valuing Bonds

Weeks 12 and 13: The Cost of Capital

The course setting itself is not difficult. Please make sure that you attend the tutorial if you are confused.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is actually a nice professor, who will explain everything clearly in his class. He also love to teach something (real-life application) more than calculating the numbers and get the scores. I feel super glad to have his class as my first finance class :))
reviews.comment_grading:
15% - 11 homework assignments (we will drop the assignment with the lowest score)
5% - Quiz on Chapters 3, 4, and 5
35% - Midterm Exam
45% - Final Exam

I got around 82.5% and got a B+. I am satisfied with it :)
Here is my suggestion:

reviews.comment_teaching:
Contrary to the majority of people here, I believe Vidan's method of teaching is both seamless and effective at the same time. His English is equivalent to a native with a moderate Indian accent.

His powerpoint slides do contain very little stuff, but he is very familiar with the subject and can deliver the course content in a very intuitive manner. He often relates the content with real-life scenarios, so you will learn additional stuff outside of the course as well.

Owning the recommended book and reading it is a must if you want to understand things comprehensively. Relying on his notes and ppt will not get you far.
reviews.comment_grading:

If you think of it as a review rather than homework, then workloads are not that high.

reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 5%
MyFinance Lab Assignments 5% +10%
Canvas Homework 15% (3 homework each counts for 5% )
Midterm 25%
Final Exam 40%

IPRS count for the participation, sometimes in the beginning of the lecture, so make sure you are on time for the lecture.
Midterm mean is 62 and SD is 19. No one can get full mark!
Final mean is 53 and also no one can get full mark! SD for final is unknown.
There are both MC and short questions in midterm. Some MC carry more marks than others like 10 marks and 8 marks.
There are only MC in Final Exam. 40MC are easier and 8MC are difficult.

I got full mark in participation which means I answered all aprs questions.
I also got MFL full mark because it only count best 9 MFL quiz and students only need to take 80% correct of each Quiz Me.
And for the homework, the mean is okay because tutor may change the mark. And for me, one homework is below mean and others are above mean.
My midterm is above 1SD.
My final is above mean 15marks.
My total score is 81%
Finally I got A- which is out of my expectation because I thought I could only get B+.
If everything is mean, you will get B.
If you slightly below mean, you will get B-.
I heard that a student total score is 79 and got B+, so the cut-off may be 80% or above to get A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Really Heavy!
I usually spend 4-5 hours per week to finish the MFL! But more time you spend, more knowledge you can get.

reviews.author: Helloitsme
reviews.comment_content: This course involves some concepts of finance(capital budgeting in particular) as well as some calculations. I suggest you to buy a financial calculator or borrow one from your senior as it will make your life much easier: at least you do not have to waste your time looking at the formula sheet in the exams. It is not a difficult course anyway.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I particularly like M.K. Lai as he is really a good professor I would say.

First, his lecture notes were so detailed, clear and well-organized that I barely needed to read the textbook. When attending his lectures, I really could feel his passion of teaching- he would cover everything that would be useful and practical in the reality (not just for the exam) even though some contents were out-of-syllabus. For his session, there would be a case study written by him, on which you would have the opportunity to apply what you have learnt in this course. If you really want to learn or even want to take finance as your major, I would suggest you to take his sessions.

Second, he was a really nice and down-to-earth professor. No matter whether it was at weekends or on the weekdays, no matter whether your questions were stupid or not, he would always be willing to reply your emails and they were very detailed (in Cantonese: not just 'hea'-ing you).
reviews.comment_grading: Both of my mid-term and final scores were above mean a little bit (the mean was quite high actually=.=) ,but my case study only met the mean. I got A- finally.
reviews.comment_workload:
Here is the assessment for my session:
Participation 3%
MyFinanceLab (MFL) 7%
Group Case Study 15%
Mid-Term Examination 30%
Final Examination 45%

For the participation: the ends of the notes of M.K. Lai would have some so-called challenging questions which would be asked in the lectures for participation. Everyone would be asked, 3 marks would be given if you answer it correctly, partial credits would also be given if you could not give the full answer but zero if you are absent. In fact, as long as you are not absent and you try to answer, M.K. Lai would give full mark to you anyway, so don't worry too much.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent teaching in terms of clear and understandable language and well-connected to the market news.

Bad teaching in terms of the many elements needed to learn yourself through MyFinance Lab as he won't cover all the content during lessons. (P.S. You can assume that those extra elements won't appear in the exam but you need them to finish MyFinance Lab)

MyFinance Lab: 15% (online homework)
Homework: 15%
Midterm: 25% (MC + 3xLQ)
Final: 40% [All MC: 40 easier problems (1.5 points each) and 8 harder questions (5 points each)]

Grading is actually the same among ALL instructors. Don't believe in the rumor.
reviews.comment_workload:
Average.

Concepts are very important. Need to understand the concept of PV, FV, EPS, etc. very clearly. The review lessons are very important as he will give you hints about the questions. (i.e. try to understand all the concepts in review lessons + underlying hints through his tone)

We don't have any sample paper. But the strong concept is better than purely crazy exam machine of doing paper.

Online homework is expected to be revised.

Even though the final exam is extremely hard (mean=53%), but you can expect many marks you can afford to lose.

Overall, his lessons are quite enjoyable and interactive!

And of course, if you are not in BBA, but in ECOF or QFIN, then you have much time to study this course (as the school always favor these students).

reviews.author: puddypie
reviews.title: Good Course because of Good Prof!
reviews.comment_content: Useful for fundamental understanding of the financial systems. Fairly simple content however the questions given during exams are tricky, with a high mean as everyone is fighting for that FINA major. Proceed with care.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Peter uses a blended- learning method form of teaching, which consists of:
1. Voiced over slides - 9 stacks :
What prof does is basically have a slide show and he voices over the content of it. Fantastic in my opinion though his tendency of putting in too much animation can be both entertaining yet distracting. What I personally do is speed it up to 1.5x / 2x as prof speaks in a relatively slower pace. However, it is extremely useful and conducive to my learning.

2. In-class Activities - 12 meetings:
What prof does is basically have a real life application of the content learned and use it in a scenario happening today. Very informative but a tad bit confusing at times if you don't listen during lectures. The videos are recorded so fred not. Do pay close attention to these as they are covered heavily during the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
A.    12 In-Class Activities (keep top 8/12) = 16%
B.    5 Homework Assignments (on Connect system; keep top 4/5) = 16%
C.    1st Midterm Exam (120 min, March 15, 19:00-21:00) = 20%
D.   2nd Midterm Exam (120 min, April 12, 19:00-21:00) = 18%
E.    Final Exam (cumulative – all course material will be covered = 30%

The grading is fantastic to be frank, however, the mean is definitely high. Cheat sheets are allowed for every exams and mock exam papers would be provided, which is an extreme boost.

I got a B in the end with everything at the mean so I would like to believe that the grading is fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very low workload in terms of graded assignments. You can consider just collaborating with your friends to get the highest marks together as there can be cross-checking methods for the online homework.

What is difficult is basically understanding the content of the course. It is straightforward yet content heavy and requires time to absorb.  However, as mentioned, the Voice Overs provided by Prof are fantastic learning materials.

reviews.author: lmaosiu4
reviews.title: I LOVE MACKAY!
reviews.comment_content:
This course has triggered my interest in my further study in Finance. The course is well-designed to build you up to be a professional.

Chapter 1: Introduction to Corporate Finance
Chapter 2: Financial Statements & Cash Flow
Chapter 3: Financial Statement Analysis & Financial Models
Chapter 4: Discounted Cash Flow Valuation
Chapter 5: Interest Rates and Bond Valuation
Chapter 6: Stock Valuation
Chapter 7: Net Present Value and Other Investment Rules
Chapter 8: Making Capital Investment Decisions
Chapter 11: Return and Risk: The Capital Asset Pricing Model
Chapter 12: Risk, Cost of Capital, and Capital Budgeting

From investment policies to financing policies, the flow of the content is well-linked and logical.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I like his classes! The professor used a lot of lively and intriguing examples to illustrate his teaching. I am definitely impressed by the Mickey Mouse Problem which illustrates the pitfall of using percentage change instead of log change. I love Prof MacKay!! I love his powerpoint slides as well. Nice PowerPoint and user-friendly!

We have Zoom audience this semester. He often engages with people on Zoom that he never ignores them, unlike other professors! And you also don't need to worry about his accent as he's from Canada. You can understand every single word from him.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair. In the past, 91% only results in B+. Similar scores for me get me an A range :)

A.  Weekly mini‐quizzes (keep top 10/13)  12%
B.  4 Homework Assignments (on Connect system)  16%
C.  Class participation (iPRS, keep top 10)  4%
D.  Midterm Exam  28%
E.  Final Exam (cumulative) 40%

Good luck everyone. As long as you practice enough, you'll get an A as well.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is manageable as long as you are self-disciplined enough to follow his suggested study schedule. We have weekly mini quizzes (only 5 questions) and a total of 4 assignments throughout the semester. So for each week, the tasks are easy to handle. You should not worry too much as the questions are easy as long as you pay attention to class!

reviews.author: olsr
reviews.title: Interesting course taught by a professional and inspiring teacher.
reviews.comment_content:
All the materials are highly correlated and make conceptual sense if you truly understand them. And Prof. MacKay loves testing students with conceptual questions.
That's why I think understanding is the most important if you take this course with MacKay.


Chapter 1: Introduction to Corporate Finance
Chapter 2: Financial Statements & Cash Flow
Chapter 3: Financial Statement Analysis & Financial Models
Chapter 4: Discounted Cash Flow Valuation
Chapter 5: Interest Rates and Bond Valuation
Chapter 6: Stock Valuation
Chapter 7: Net Present Value and Other Investment Rules
Chapter 8: Making Capital Investment Decisions
Chapter 11: Return and Risk: The Capital Asset Pricing Model
Chapter 12: Risk, Cost of Capital, and Capital Budgeting
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. MacKay is definitely the one-of-a-kind teacher you would have ever met in a life time. His passion in teaching could be seen even in the first lecture. He explains every subtle details clearly with valid examples, I am enchanted with the bullet example he used to describe and explain the CAPM model, which was exceptionally useful in helping me understand the concept. Also, his PowerPoint slides are colourful and informative where you can study them with the help of VOS, which explains the materials nicely and concisely.
For his teaching style. He is so caring and always interacts with students. That’s why there was a day where the lecture room was full of students and there weren’t even enough seats. There are 6 IPRS during each class, but the first question is always asking students about their day, which gives us so much love and warmth. Also, he will make sure every student is ready in order to run the IPRS countdown, so there is nothing to be stressed about.

Grading is great.
I heard that people got 87% in overall grade and got an A-
I got 95.8% in overall and got A+
